state.original_message: Aren't all processed foods filled with harmful chemicals? Shouldn't I avoid them entirely?
state.enhanced_message:
### SOURCE
[1] (Food & Nutrition Handbook) - Discourage processing practices that contaminate the agricul- ture harvest. - Promote good storage practices that ensure safe and nutri - tious foods. - Not all food should go to the market.

[2] (Food & Nutrition Handbook) Discourage processing practices that produce microbial contaminate of the agricultural harvest - Ensure crop is not left on the ground or on bare soil during drying, shelling and threshing, where fungal spores develop. The practice of moistening the unshelled nuts to make them easier to shell results in higher contamination from aflatoxin and should therefore be strictly discouraged.

[3] (Food & Nutrition Handbook) - Avoid taking raw or partially cooked foods of animal origin. - All food grains and seeds such as maize and groundnuts should be properly dried and stored in a dry place. Use clean stores for storing foods.

[4] (Food & Nutrition Handbook) - Keep cooked food away from contact with raw food. - Avoid eating mouldy or rotten food. - Avoid taking oil seeds whose skin has been cracked, e.g., ground - nuts, soybeans.

[5] (Food & Nutrition Handbook) - Avoid physical or mechanical damage during harvesting, transportation and handling of foods. - Avoid drying, shelling, threshing and winnowing food on bare ground (problems with contamination by microorganisms, sand and stones). - Sort and clean the food to remove diseased and poor quality produce and impurities.

[6] (Food & Nutrition Handbook) Street foods, food vending, restau-rants and hotels have become quite common of recent. Food becomes unsafe for human consumption when the concentrations of the following (referred to as hazards) are above tolerance levels: - Microorganisms (bacteria, fungi, viruses), parasites - Biological toxins such as mycotoxins - Physical materials like metal chips, sand, faecal material, stones - Chemical residues including heavy metals such as lead, mercury, copper and others Microorganisms including (bacteria, fungi, viruses) are the leading cause of food poisoning in the world. Physical aspects of food items affected by microbial activity with potential toxin formation include the following: - Discoloration - Mouldy and other unpleasant tastes - Production of off odour Aflatoxins caused by the moulds of aspergillusspp are especially asso - ciated with occurrence of liver cancer in humans.

Physical aspects of food items affected by microbial activity with potential toxin formation include the following: - Discoloration - Mouldy and other unpleasant tastes - Production of off odour Aflatoxins caused by the moulds of aspergillusspp are especially asso - ciated with occurrence of liver cancer in humans. There is also growing evidence that aflatoxins and mycotoxins in general can lead to reduced immunity and other associated effects such as incidence of HIV/AIDS and undernutrition.

[8] (Food & Nutrition Handbook) - Avoid eating mouldy or rotten food. - Avoid taking oil seeds whose skin has been cracked, e.g., ground - nuts, soybeans. - Wash vegetables with plenty of water at least three times before cutting it.

[9] (Food & Nutrition Handbook) Should strictly take drugs on advice of the health personnel as some of them are potentially harmful to the unborn child. 9. Avoid negative cultural practices that reduce the intake of nutritious foods or impact negatively on their health such as: - Not consuming chicken and eggs.

[10] (Food & Nutrition Handbook) - Avoid drying, shelling, threshing and winnowing food on bare ground (problems with contamination by microorganisms, sand and stones). - Sort and clean the food to remove diseased and poor quality produce and impurities. - Make sure that the produce is prepared under hygienic condi - tions all the time.

### QUESTION
Aren't all processed foods filled with harmful chemicals? Shouldn't I avoid them entirely?

question: Do I really need to drink at least 12 cups of water a day, regardless of my size or activity level?
initial_answer: The recommendation is a minimum of 2-3 Litres per day for an adult person, which is equivalent to at least 8 cups a day (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [1], [3], [4]. Children should drink all the time as they need (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [2], [3], [5]. Individual carbohydrate requirements vary according to age, sex, physical activity level, and physiological status (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [7], [8].
final_answer: The recommendation is a minimum of 2-3 Litres per day for an adult person, which is equivalent to at least 8 cups a day (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [1], [3], [4]. Children should drink all the time as they need (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [2], [3], [5]. Individual carbohydrate requirements vary according to age, sex, physical activity level, and physiological status (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [7], [8].

question: I've read that vitamin C supplements can cure colds rapidly. Is this true?
initial_answer: Vitamin C is an antioxidant that fights and resists infection (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [3] and (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [8]. It is found in fruits and vegetables, especially citrus fruits, tomatoes, peppers, strawberries, and cantaloupe (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [3] and (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [8]. It also heals wounds and promotes growth and maintenance of bones, teeth, gums, ligaments, and blood vessels (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [3] and (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [8]. The recommended intake of Vitamin C is 100-200 mg (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [3] and (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [8].

question: How many calories should I eat in a day to stay healthy?
initial_answer: The recommended daily carbohydrate intake should provide about 45% to 65% of the total body energy/calorie requirements of 2000 -3000 kilocalories (kcal) (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [1], [3], [4].
final_answer: The recommended daily carbohydrate intake should provide about 45% to 65% of the total body energy/calorie requirements of 2000 -3000 kilocalories (kcal) (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [1], [3], [4].

question: What should I eat to get stronger muscles?
initial_answer: To build muscles, consume zinc and iron (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [1], [8]. Sources of zinc include beef, seafood, liver, nuts, beans, and whole grains (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [1]. Sources of iron include meat, liver, eggs, dark-green leafy vegetables (DGLV), seeds, wholegrain, legumes, fish, and seafood (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [8].
final_answer: To build muscles, consume zinc and iron (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [1], [8]. Sources of zinc include beef, seafood, liver, nuts, beans, and whole grains (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [1]. Sources of iron include meat, liver, eggs, dark-green leafy vegetables (DGLV), seeds, wholegrain, legumes, fish, and seafood (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [8].

question: I don’t like eating vegetables much. How can I still be healthy?
initial_answer: To stay healthy, eat a variety of food types from the three main food groups (energy giving, body building, and protective foods) at every meal (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [2] and (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [5]. For lunch and supper, have a fruit and a serving of vegetables (100g or one handful of fresh vegetables) (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [1], (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [2], and (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [5]. You can select dark green leafy vegetables (DGLV), e.g., dodo, malakwang, (at least one serving per day) and yellow fruits (ripe bananas [2 small ripe apple/sweet bananas or 1 bogoya per day], one orange or one mango) (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [6] and (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [9]. Two guavas per day can be very healthy and can substitute citrus fruits (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [8] and (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [9].
final_answer: I don't know.

question: Can you suggest a simple vegetarian diet plan?
initial_answer:
- Eat a variety of food types from different main three groups (energy giving, body building and protective foods) at a very meal (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [1] and (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [6].
- Eat a lot of whole cereals and beans or legumes generally, if you can’t afford animal protein and as much as possible take some milk in your meals (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [6].
- For lunch and supper take a fruit and a serving of vegetables (100g or one handful of fresh vegetables) (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [1], (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [6], and (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [10].
- Eat more of cereals (millet, maize and sorghum) compared to tubers (cassava, sweet potato and banana) (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [4].
final_answer:
- Eat a variety of food types from different main three groups (energy giving, body building and protective foods) at a very meal (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [1] and (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [6].
- Eat a lot of whole cereals and beans or legumes generally, if you can’t afford animal protein and as much as possible take some milk in your meals (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [6].
- For lunch and supper take a fruit and a serving of vegetables (100g or one handful of fresh vegetables) (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [1], (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [6], and (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [10].
- Eat more of cereals (millet, maize and sorghum) compared to tubers (cassava, sweet potato and banana) (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [4].

question: What foods help clear up skin?
initial_answer: Beta carotene is found in dark green and deep yellow fruits and vegetables and maintains healthy skin and hair (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [9]. Zinc, found in shellfish, organ meats, lean red meat, yeast, whole-grain cereals, and legumes, is involved in skin health (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [7]. Vitamin B3, found in meat, organ meats, whole grains and cereals, legumes, eggs, milk, and green leafy vegetables, maintains healthy skin (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [10].
final_answer: Beta carotene is found in dark green and deep yellow fruits and vegetables and maintains healthy skin and hair (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [9]. Zinc, found in shellfish, organ meats, lean red meat, yeast, whole-grain cereals, and legumes, is involved in skin health (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [7]. Vitamin B3, found in meat, organ meats, whole grains and cereals, legumes, eggs, milk, and green leafy vegetables, maintains healthy skin (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [10].

question: How much water should I drink every day?
initial_answer: To avoid dehydration, adults should drink a minimum of 2-3 Litres of water per day (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [1], (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [2], (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [3]. This can include drinks such as tea, coffee, and fruit juice, and should total at least 8 cups a day (for an adult) (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [1], (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [3], (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [4]. Children should drink water all the time as they need (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [3], (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [4], (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [5].
final_answer: To avoid dehydration, adults should drink a minimum of 2-3 Litres of water per day (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [1], (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [2], (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [3]. This can include drinks such as tea, coffee, and fruit juice, and should total at least 8 cups a day (for an adult) (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [1], (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [3], (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [4]. Children should drink water all the time as they need (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [3], (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [4], (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [5].

question: Can I eat rice if I'm diabetic?
initial_answer: If you have diabetes, it's important to minimize consumption of sweet foods such as sugar, jam, cakes, and sugary drinks because they do not provide any other nutrients and may increase risk of overweight (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [10]. Fiber can slow the body’s absorption of sugar and cholesterol protecting the body from diseases of the heart and diabetes (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [6] and (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [7].
final_answer: If you have diabetes, it's important to minimize consumption of sweet foods such as sugar, jam, cakes, and sugary drinks because they do not provide any other nutrients and may increase risk of overweight (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [10]. Fiber can slow the body’s absorption of sugar and cholesterol protecting the body from diseases of the heart and diabetes (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [6] and (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [7].

initial_answer: To manage sugar cravings, avoid eating too much sugar (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [7], (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [8], and sweet foods such as sugar, jam, cakes and sugary drinks, as they should be consumed minimally (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [3], (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [5], (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [6]. question: What's a quick healthy lunch I can make for work?
initial_answer:
To make a quick, healthy lunch for work, consider these guidelines (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [1], (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [2], and (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [4]:
- Eat a variety of food types from the main three food groups: energy-giving, body-building, and protective foods (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [1], (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [4].
- Include a fruit and a serving of vegetables (100g or one handful of fresh vegetables) (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [1], (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [2], (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [4].
final_answer:
To make a quick, healthy lunch for work, consider these guidelines (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [1], (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [2], and (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [4]:
- Eat a variety of food types from the main three food groups: energy-giving, body-building, and protective foods (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [1], (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [4].
- Include a fruit and a serving of vegetables (100g or one handful of fresh vegetables) (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [1], (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [2], (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [4].

question: How much protein do I need if I don’t work out?
initial_answer: The recommended daily intake of protein is about 1 gram per kilogram of body weight (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [1]. For example, a person weighing 60 kg requires 60 grams of protein each day. This amount is equivalent to one egg or a piece of meat about the size of an egg (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [1].
final_answer: The recommended daily intake of protein is about 1 gram per kilogram of body weight (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [1]. For example, a person weighing 60 kg requires 60 grams of protein each day. This amount is equivalent to one egg or a piece of meat about the size of an egg (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [1].

question: What are some iron-rich foods that aren’t meat?
initial_answer: Some iron-rich foods that aren’t meat include whole-wheat products, shell fish, nuts, dried fruit, legumes, and leafy green vegetables (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [1], [2], [3]. Many breads and cereals are enriched with iron (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [1], [2], [8].
final_answer: Some iron-rich foods that aren’t meat include whole-wheat products, shell fish, nuts, dried fruit, legumes, and leafy green vegetables (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [1], [2], [3]. Many breads and cereals are enriched with iron (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [1], [2], [8].

question: What is immediate consequence fo malnutrition
initial_answer: Consequences of malnutrition include increased illness and death, poor growth and development, lower labor productivity, poorer educational attainment, and noncommunicable diseases like diabetes and hypertension (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [1], [2], and [3]. Malnutrition can also lead to multiple medical conditions including coronary heart disease, diabetes, gout, hypertension, overweight, obesity, and even death (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [6] and [8]. More than half of infant deaths are associated with malnutrition (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [6] and [8]. Vitamin A deficiency causes blindness (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [9].
final_answer: Consequences of malnutrition include increased illness and death, poor growth and development, lower labor productivity, poorer educational attainment, and noncommunicable diseases like diabetes and hypertension (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [1], [2], and [3]. Malnutrition can also lead to multiple medical conditions including coronary heart disease, diabetes, gout, hypertension, overweight, obesity, and even death (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [6] and [8]. More than half of infant deaths are associated with malnutrition (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [6] and [8]. Vitamin A deficiency causes blindness (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [9].

They are a primary source of energy (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [5], (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [6], and (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [7].

state.enhanced_message:
### SOURCE
[1] (Food & Nutrition Handbook) Macronutrient Macronutrients are required by the body in large amounts and include carbohydrates, proteins and fat. Micronutrient Micronutrients are required by the body in small amounts and include vitamins and minerals. Nutritious diets Consumption of a variety food that can potentially supply all the body nutritional requirements on a daily basis.

[2] (Food & Nutrition Handbook) Food and Nutrition Handbook for Extension WorkersxKitoobero A Luganda dialect used to describe a multi-mix food of locally available foods from three or more food groups prepared to preserve nutrients in a balanced manner with the consistency and taste that is child friendly (especially for children under five years). Macronutrient Macronutrients are required by the body in large amounts and include carbohydrates, proteins and fat. Micronutrient Micronutrients are required by the body in small amounts and include vitamins and minerals.

[3] (Food & Nutrition Handbook) Food and Nutrition Handbook for Extension Workers5Nutrients in food Nutrients are substances contained in food that nourish the body. question: What is a good source of calcium
initial_answer: The major source of calcium in the world is milk and milk products (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [1], [2], [3]. Other sources include fish eaten with bones (silver fish—mukene, haplochromis species—nkeje) and dark green vegetables (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [1], [2]. You can also find it in legumes, shellfish, fish with edible bones, tofu, and calcium-fortified orange juice (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [7], [9].
final_answer: The major source of calcium in the world is milk and milk products (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [1], [2], [3]. Other sources include fish eaten with bones (silver fish—mukene, haplochromis species—nkeje) and dark green vegetables (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [1], [2]. You can also find it in legumes, shellfish, fish with edible bones, tofu, and calcium-fortified orange juice (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [7], [9].

question: Why is iodine important to diet
initial_answer: Iodine is important for thyroid function and mental development in children (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [1], [2], [3]. It helps the brain and body to function properly and is essential to the healthy development of unborn babies and young children, as well as helping pregnant women (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [4]. A shortage of iodine decreases IQ and causes a productivity loss (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [7]. The recommended daily allowance of iodine is 150 µg (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [9]. Adequate iodine intake during pregnancy is crucial to normal fetal development (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [5], [9].
final_answer: Iodine is important for thyroid function and mental development in children (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [1], [2], [3]. It helps the brain and body to function properly and is essential to the healthy development of unborn babies and young children, as well as helping pregnant women (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [4]. A shortage of iodine decreases IQ and causes a productivity loss (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [7]. The recommended daily allowance of iodine is 150 µg (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [9]. Adequate iodine intake during pregnancy is crucial to normal fetal development (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [5], [9].

question: Why does the body need  minerals
initial_answer: Minerals are required for normal body functions such as growth, development, water balance, and neurological processes (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [3]. They are also very important in protecting the body against infections (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [7] and (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [9].
final_answer: Minerals are required for normal body functions such as growth, development, water balance, and neurological processes (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [3]. They are also very important in protecting the body against infections (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [7] and (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [9].

question: Why is water needed?
initial_answer:
Water is needed:
*   To transport nutrients around the body (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [3] and (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [6].
*   To make blood, saliva, tears, and sweat (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [3] and (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [6].
*   To enable body processes such as digestion (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [3].
*   To maintain fluid balance and cell turgidity (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [4].
*   As a medium for all biochemical reactions in the body and as a solvent for certain nutrients (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [4].
*   To remove excreta (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [4].
*   To keep some parts of the body moist (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [4].
*   To keep the mouth and lungs moist, and to keep the skin moist and cool (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [7].
*   To produce breast milk, which is also a source of water (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [5] and (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [7].
final_answer:
Water is needed:
*   To transport nutrients around the body (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [3] and (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [6].
*   To make blood, saliva, tears, and sweat (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [3] and (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [6].
*   To enable body processes such as digestion (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [3].
*   To maintain fluid balance and cell turgidity (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [4].
*   As a medium for all biochemical reactions in the body and as a solvent for certain nutrients (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [4].
*   To remove excreta (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [4].
*   To keep some parts of the body moist (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [4].
*   To keep the mouth and lungs moist, and to keep the skin moist and cool (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [7].
*   To produce breast milk, which is also a source of water (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [5] and (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [7].

question: Should extra water be consumed when breast feeding?
initial_answer: Yes, extra water is needed in lactation when extra water is required for milk production (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [4] and (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [7]. Breastfeeding mothers should also take a lot of fluids to cater for the high amounts of water used to make breast milk (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [1], (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [2], and (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [5].
final_answer: Yes, extra water is needed in lactation when extra water is required for milk production (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [4] and (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [7]. Breastfeeding mothers should also take a lot of fluids to cater for the high amounts of water used to make breast milk (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [1], (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [2], and (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [5].

question: Why is good nutrition important?
initial_answer:
Good nutrition:
- Enhances physical and cognitive development (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [1], [2], and [3].
- Enhances breast milk production for the mother to adequately breastfeed her child (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [1] and [2].
- Builds and/or boosts body immunity, reducing susceptibility to disease (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [1].
- Makes an individual healthy, more productive, and improves the quality of life (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [4] and [6].

Good nutrition is important throughout the life cycle, from pre-conception to adulthood (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [4], [5], and [6].
final_answer:
Good nutrition:
- Enhances physical and cognitive development (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [1], [2], and [3].
- Enhances breast milk production for the mother to adequately breastfeed her child (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [1] and [2].
- Builds and/or boosts body immunity, reducing susceptibility to disease (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [1].
- Makes an individual healthy, more productive, and improves the quality of life (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [4] and [6].

Good nutrition is important throughout the life cycle, from pre-conception to adulthood (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [4], [5], and [6].

question: What causes Night Blindness
initial_answer: Night blindness can be caused by vitamin A deficiency (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [1], (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [2], (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [3], (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [5], (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [6], and eye problems (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [7].
final_answer: Night blindness can be caused by vitamin A deficiency (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [1], (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [2], (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [3], (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [5], (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [6], and eye problems (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [7].

question: What is a balanced diet
initial_answer: A balanced diet is a feeding pattern that provides adequate amounts of nutrients in their correct proportions as required by the body at a particular time (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [1], [2], [3]. To get enough nutrients, adults need at least three balanced meals a day, and children need at least five (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [1], [2], [4]. Attaining a balanced diet requires that one eats various food stuffs in a day and makes careful food choices from different food groups (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [1], [4], [5]. It also requires eating food in the right proportions and quality as required by the body (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [1], [4], [5].
final_answer: A balanced diet is a feeding pattern that provides adequate amounts of nutrients in their correct proportions as required by the body at a particular time (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [1], [2], [3]. To get enough nutrients, adults need at least three balanced meals a day, and children need at least five (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [1], [2], [4]. Attaining a balanced diet requires that one eats various food stuffs in a day and makes careful food choices from different food groups (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [1], [4], [5]. It also requires eating food in the right proportions and quality as required by the body (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [1], [4], [5].

question: What are sources of protein other than animal sources
initial_answer: Legumes and nuts are good sources of plant protein (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [1], [2], [4]. Other plant-based sources of protein include soybeans, peas, cow peas, pigeon peas, common beans, and ground nuts (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [7], [10].

question: What dietary needs do pregnant women have
initial_answer: Pregnant women need foods rich in iron and vitamin A in addition to a balanced diet (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [1] and (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [3]. Iron needs are highly increased partly due to the need to build reserves for the child up to six months after birth before initiating complementary food intake (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [1], (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [3], and (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [5]. They also need to take foods rich in calcium, e.g., milk and mukene (silver fish) partly to take care of the increased requirement for building the foetus skeletal structure (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [1], (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [2], and (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [5]. They have higher needs for nutrients generally and should take snacks in between meals (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [2], (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [5], and (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [6]. They should also take iron and folate tablets daily in addition to foods rich in iron, calcium, and vitamin A (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [7], (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [8], and (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [10]. They need to eat more food rather than decrease the intake (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [4]. A pregnant woman should eat a variety of foods from the main food groups daily (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [10].

Iron needs are highly increased partly due to the need to build reserves for the child up to six months after birth before initiating complementary food intake (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [1], (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [3], and (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [5]. question: should fruits and vegetables be washed before eating.
initial_answer: Yes, universal precautions apply to food handling, like washing raw fruits and vegetables (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [4]. Always wash fruits before giving them to a child (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [7]. Wash vegetables with plenty of water at least three times before cutting (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [3], (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [5], and (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [6]. Washing fruits before slicing and eating them is one of the main ways of preventing infections (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [2].
final_answer: Yes, universal precautions apply to food handling, like washing raw fruits and vegetables (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [4]. Always wash fruits before giving them to a child (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [7]. Wash vegetables with plenty of water at least three times before cutting (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [3], (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [5], and (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [6]. Washing fruits before slicing and eating them is one of the main ways of preventing infections (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [2].

question: How dangerous is undercooked food
initial_answer: Food may become unsafe for human consumption when the concentrations of hazards are above tolerance levels (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [1], [3], [4]. Microorganisms are the leading cause of food poisoning in the world (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [1], [3], [4]. Food safety is a public health priority because millions of people worldwide fall ill every year and many die as a result of eating unsafe food (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [8].

question: Give me a recipe for a porridge
initial_answer:
Here are some recipes for enriched porridges (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [1], [2], [3], [4], [5]:

**Cereal and legumes**
*   Ingredients: 90 g cereal (millet, sorghum, maize, rice), 90 g legume (beans, peas, pulses, soya), 20 g sugar, 1.5 litres of water
*   Instructions: Soak legume overnight, remove testa and boil until soft and mash. Cook cereal porridge (gruel) as usual. Add the legume, mix and simmer for 2-3 minutes. Add sugar and serve.

**Cereal and nuts**
*   Ingredients: 90 g cereal (millet, sorghum, maize, rice), 90 g groundnuts or cashew nuts, 20 g sugar, 1.5 litres of water
*   Instructions: Toast nuts, remove cover and pound or grind to a soft paste. Mix with hot water to make a thick soup. Cook cereal porridge (gruel) as usual. Add the nut mixture, mix well and simmer for 2-3 minutes. Add sugar and serve.

**Nuts and seeds**
*   Ingredients: 90 g nuts (groundnuts, cashew-nuts), 20 g seeds (sesame, sunflower), 20 g sugar, 1 Litre of water
*   Instructions: Toast nuts and seeds in turn. Remove cover and pound or grind to soft paste. Mix with hot water to make thick soup. Cook cereal porridge (gruel) as usual. Add the nut and seed mixture, mix well and simmer for 2-3 minutes. Add sugar and serve.

**Cereal and animal products**
*   Ingredients: 90 g cereal (millet, sorghum, maize, rice), 1 medium-sized egg, 20 g sugar, 1.5 litres of water
*   Instructions: Make porridge from cereals. Put egg in cold water and heat. Remove egg just as the water starts boiling. Beat up the egg and mix in the porridge. Add sugar and serve

**Cereal, tubers, and seeds**
*   Ingredients: 90 grams cereal (millet, sorghum, maize, rice), 90 g seeds (sim-sim, sorghum), 90 g root flour (cassava, taro, potato), 100 g nuts (groundnuts, cashew nuts),

question: how much carbohydrates should an adult eat
initial_answer: Individual carbohydrate requirements vary according to age, sex, physical activity level, and physiological status (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [10]. The recommended daily carbohydrate intake should provide about 45% to 65% of the total body energy/calorie requirements of 2000 -3000 kilocalories (kcal) (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [1] and (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [2].
final_answer: Individual carbohydrate requirements vary according to age, sex, physical activity level, and physiological status (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [10]. The recommended daily carbohydrate intake should provide about 45% to 65% of the total body energy/calorie requirements of 2000 -3000 kilocalories (kcal) (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [1] and (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [2].
